PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1. The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  this  technically  complex  and
multisector project covering four medium-sized cities is necessary to carefully study economic 
plans  and  potentials,  refine  economic  development  strategy,  assess and  identify  the most 
suitable  subcomponents  that  will  facilitate  economic  development  and  non-coal  industrial 
transformation, provide innovative and international best practices, further define the scope and 
optimize the project impact, carry out the necessary due diligence to ensure project viability and 
sustainability, facilitate value addition to the project, and provide training to the provincial and 
participating city governments. 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2. The TA will be implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will develop an economic strategy
and investment program. Consultants will (i) conduct a subregional economic diagnostic study 
and prepare a non-coal industry development strategy for the East Heilongjiang city cluster and 
the project cities; (ii) identify key economic activities and industries focusing on endogenous 
potentials and exploring further implementable possibilities; (iii) prepare an investment strategy 
and phased investment program; (iv) identify priority infrastructure that is expected to facilitate 
the proposed industrial transformation to be financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
loan;  (v)  assess  mining  impact  and  prepare  a  mining  remediation  strategy,  identify  key 
environmental cleanup projects, and coal mining remediation pilots to be financed by the loan; 
and (vi) identify urban infrastructure and services that can be delivered through public-private 
partnerships.  
3. Phase 2 will specify the plans and conduct due diligence to prepare a project for ADB
financing. Consultants will (i) further develop and refine the economic and non-coal industry 
development  plans;  (ii)  prepare  the  non-structural  components  of  the  project  including 
(a) strategic non-coal industry development implementation action plan for the subregion and 
the project cities, (b) labor force planning and human resource development strategy supporting 
the anticipated new industries with technical and vocational education and training, (c) private 
sector finance programs, (d) mining remediation management plan, and (e)  East Heilongjiang 
smart  city  cluster  cooperation  strategy  and  branding,  marketing,  and  exchange  platform 
development;  and  (iii)  conduct  full  due  diligence  on  technical,  environmental  and  social 
safeguards, and economic and financial aspects for all structural components.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
4. The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000 which will be financed on a grant basis for
$800,000 from ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and $300,000 
from  the  Urban  Environmental  Infrastructure  Fund  under  the  Urban  Financing  Partnership 
Facility.1 The government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in the form of  counterpart  staff, 
secretarial  assistance,  domestic  transportation,  provision  of  office  space,  communication 
facilities, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2. 
Proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time).

D.  Consulting Services 
5. Phase 1 will be carried out by individual consultants while phase 2 will be done by a
consulting firm. The individual consultants will be engaged for a total of 22 person-months (13 
international and 9 national). An international climate change specialist and hydrologist will be

6. Economic  revitalization,  non-coal  industrial  transformation  planning,  and
investment program development. Four experts (11 person-months) will (i) collect data and 
review national, provincial, regional, and municipal economic and social development plans and 
relevant policies and guiding documents; (ii) prepare a subregional economic diagnostic study 
and  development  strategy;    (iii)  carry  out  workshops  in  the  cities  on  regional  and  urban 
economic development and non-coal industrial transformation; (iv) identify key strategies and 
associated key investment components that facilitate non-coal economic transformation; and 
(v) develop a prioritized and phased investment program identifying subcomponents to be 
financed by the loan. 
2  ADB’s Climate Change Fund will finance $100,000 to conduct climate risk and vulnerability assessment through its 
direct charge modality.

4   
7. Mining remediation management and environmental cleanup plan. Two experts (6
person-months) will assess mining impact and develop an integrated mining remediation plan 
for the subregion and the project cities. They will assess mining impacts on environmental 
degradation and pollution and develop a subregional environmental cleanup plan and city-
specific plans to mitigate mining impacts. 
8. Technical.  Indicatively  12  experts  (36  person-months)  will  review  and  recommend
technical solutions to the overall sector systems plans for effective and efficient integration of 
much needed basic infrastructure and services identified during Phase 1. The consultants will 
review and prepare a technical report on strategies, plans, and designs of all components to 
ensure  that  they  (i)  are  properly  scaled  to  meet  demand,  (ii)  are  technically  sound  and 
compatible  with  local  conditions,  (iii)  meet  all  relevant  technical  standards  and  safeguard 
requirements,  and  (iv)  are  suitable  for  ADB  financing.  The  consultants  will  perform  risk 
assessment  for  projects  and  associated  projects  and  recommend  innovations  and 
improvements to refine the technical design of each subcomponent. 
9. Financial and economic. Four experts (11 person-months) will conduct economic and
financial analyses of all components and the overall project including demand assessments, 
contingent valuation survey results analysis, cost effectiveness analysis of various options, 
including the without project option, and affordability analysis, meeting ADB requirements.3 
Economic rationale will be developed and economic justification will be evaluated for each 
component and the project as a whole. The consultants will undertake financial reviews and 
analysis of each project component, and detailed assessment of the financial performance of 
the implementing agencies and project implementation units (PIUs) in accordance with ADB 
guidelines.4 This includes assessments and analyses of (i) financial management and strength 
and internal and external audit systems of implementing agencies and PIUs; (ii) soundness of 
financing  plan  and  counterpart  funding;  (iii)  possible  cofinancing  sources,  including  private 
sector especially for revenue-generating components; (iv) least-cost, cost-benefit, and fiscal 
analyses; and (v) financial and affordability analyses of revenue-generating components and 
review of tariffs and fees.5   
10. Environment. Two experts (8 person-months) will prepare an EIA across the project
cities based on the review of the subproject EIAs and ensure that they meet the requirements of 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The consultants will prepare a consolidated EIA, 
including an environmental management plan both in English and in Chinese in ADB’s required 
format. The consultants will guide the implementing agencies, PIUs, local institutes, and the EIA 
preparation  team  on  ADB’s  environmental  assessment  requirements.  A  climate  risk  and 
vulnerability  assessment  will  be  conducted  including  hydrologic  modelling  and 
recommendations  for  structural  and  non-structural  measures  to  mitigate  climate  risks  and 
variability. A water safety plan will be prepared in association with the water supply components 
including recommendations for project design.

11. Involuntary resettlement and ethnic minority. One or two experts (6 person-months)
will review draft resettlement plans and assist the implementing agencies to engage a qualified 
survey institute to conduct surveys, and improve and finalize resettlement plans in accordance 
with ADB requirements.6 The consultants will conduct a thorough scoping of ethnic minority 
issues in the project area and confirm category C for indigenous peoples safeguards (or, if 
deemed  necessary,  prepare  ethnic  minority  development  plan)  in  accordance  with  ADB 
requirements.7  
12. Social and poverty. One or two experts (5 person-months) and a survey team will carry
out a poverty and social survey and analysis, and assess the project’s short- and long-term 
impacts and benefits for poor and vulnerable groups, including gender analysis in accordance 
with ADB requirements.8 Based on the analysis, the consultants will prepare a summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy, a social development action plan, and a gender action plan in 
accordance with ADB guidelines and templates. 9 
13. Governance and risk management. Two experts (7 person-months) will prepare (i) a
procurement risk assessment of the implementing agencies and PIUs in accordance with ADB 
guidelines  and  templates,10 (ii)  a  procurement  plan,  (iii)  master  bidding  documents,  and 
(iv)  conduct  training  on  ADB’s  procurement  and  consultant  engagement  guidelines.  The 
consultants  will  assess  the  financial  management  system,  accounting  rules  and  practices, 
administrative  procedures,  internal  control  and  audit  systems,  external  audit,  technical 
capabilities  of  the  implementing  agencies  and  identify  potential  risks  in  public  financial 
management,  procurement,  anticorruption,  and  technical;  and  prepare  a  governance  risk 
assessment  and  management  plan.  The  consultants  will  facilitate  cross-sector  and  inter-
jurisdiction coordination.  
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
14. Heilongjiang  Provincial  Government  will  be  the  project  executing  agency.  The  city
governments of Hegang, Jixi, Qitaihe, and Shuangyashan will be the project implementing 
agencies, each with a subproject leading group and a subproject management office. Project 
implementation units will be established under the concerned city administration bureaus or 
investment companies that are the final owners and operators of the subprojects. The proposed 
TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.
